results.title: Stroszek
results.creator_credit: Werner Herzog and Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen
results.brief_description: Bruno Stroszek is a contemporary equivalent of Kaspar Hauser. The story was actually inspired by the life of Bruno S. who plays Stroszek. Bruno and his two friends form an oddly assorted trio who escape from Berlin’s low-life to Wisconsin in search of an ‘American dream’ which quickly turns sour. What begins as a low-life melodrama with a realistic edge becomes an absurdist road movie then a metaphysical quest. Bruno’s isolation is lent an underlying perverse logic by Herzog’s favourite circle motif recalling Bruno’s early remark that ‘it (life) all goes round in circles’. Cast includes Bruno S., Eva Mattes, Clemens Scheitz. In German with English subtitles.

results.title: Strictly ballroom
results.creator_credit: M and A Productions, Tristram Miall and Baz Luhrmann
results.brief_description: The hit of the Cannes Film Festival of 1992 is a spirited, allegorical musical about a young, competitive ballroom dancer who outrages his mother and the “establishment” by insisting on dancing his own provocative steps and taking on a new ugly-duckling partner who blooms under his tutelage. Ballet dancer Paul Mercurio shot to fame with this film. He is partnered by Tara Morice and supported by Barry Otto, Gia Carides and Bill Hunter.

results.title: Street of shame = Akasen chitai [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Janus Films, Daiei Motion Picture Company, Masaichi Nagata and Kenji Mizoguchi
results.brief_description: The setting is a Tokyo brothel, ironically called Dreamland. The content is the thoughts, disappointments and aspirations of the occupants. This was Mizoguchi’s final film, and one in which he returned to his earlier theme of the exploitation of women throughout the ages. He does so by integrating the stories of five prostitutes which covers the roles of women as daughters, mothers and wives. Many believe that this film was pivotal in the 1957 decision to abolish prostitution in Japan. Cast includes Daisuke Kato, Machiko Kyo and Aiko Mimasu.

results.title: Street fighter II: the animated movie
results.creator_credit: Capcom Productions, Kenichi Imai and Gisaburo Sugii
results.brief_description: Based on the popular video game of the same name. Human civilisation is under attack in the not so distant future. Bison is the evil mastermind who leads the forces of evil and wants to take possession of the world’s best fighters so he can use them to conquer the world. Ken and Ryu are the only two humans in the world with the skill and strength to stop them. What ensues is a mighty battle in the classic clash between the forces of good and evil.

results.title: Streamers
results.creator_credit: Rank Film Productions, Streamers International, Nick Mileti and Robert Altman
results.brief_description: Set in an Army barracks in 1965, a group of young soldiers wait assignment to Vietnam. The draftees come from diverse backgrounds: two are afro-americans, one a country boy and the other a Yale-educated homosexual. They are confronted by two brutal ex-Korean war veteran sergeants. Sexual and racial tensions build as the men wait in their claustrophobic barracks but eventually shocking violence erupts. The barracks is a microcosm of the explosive emotions and issues which surfaced in America at that time, however the theatrical nature of the original material, (based on a play by David Rabe) is reflected in a static production which is more stagebound than fluid. The performances, especially by Matthew Modine, Michael Wright and George Dzundza are superb.

results.title: Stray dog = Nora Inu
results.creator_credit: Shintoho, Toho Kabushiki Kaisha, Shojiro Motoki and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description: A young detective Murakami (Toshiro Mifune) has his police gun pick-pocketed on a packed bus in Tokyo. Fearing dismissal, Murakami trawls Tokyo’s underbelly encountering a slew of criminals, black market gunrunners and sleazy types in his quest to recover his weapon and halt the murders occurring at the hand of the thief. In Kurosawa’s ninth feature, the pace is languorous, reflecting the oppressive heat of Occupied Tokyo, sapping the resistance of the many characters that pepper the narrative, sweating their way through an excessive heatwave, battling poverty whilst living amid slums and atrocious post-war conditions. Kurosawa presents a fine example of a noir detective movie, exhibiting his technical virtuosity in a series of vignettes as Murakami chases thieves through grimy back alleys, and sleazy dancehalls, as his naivete ebbs away. Gloomy, intense and atmospheric, this film, about an obsessive quest, delineates a loss of innocence for a rookie cop in search of truth where poverty and degradation causes desperation and amorality to thrive in an urban setting. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Strawberry and chocolate = fresa y chocolate
results.creator_credit: Cuban Institute of Arts and Film Industry, Imcine, Tabasco Films, Miguel Mendoza, Tomas Gutierrez Alea and Juan Carlos Tabio
results.brief_description: A young Cuban Communist Party cadre is shocked to find himself pursued by a witty, handsome homosexual. By exploring the friendship that develops between a straight man and a gay man in a culture which forbids open expression of homosexuality, “Strawberry and Chocolate” manages to raise important political questions while remaining delightfully comic throughout. The film exposes Cuba’s anti-gay laws by showing the important role gay and lesbian revolutionaries, writers and artists played in Cuban culture and examines how political censorship in any context only impoverishes a society. Jorge Perugorria and Vladimir Cruz are excellent as the two friends and Mirta Ibarra steals every scene she is in as a vivacious and sexy Cuban woman who refuses to allow Latin machismo to dictate her life and choices.

results.title: Strangers on a train
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures and Alfred Hitchcock
results.brief_description: Based on Patricia Highsmith’s chilling thriller, “Strangers on a train”, this is one of Alfred Hitchcock’s most suspenseful and exciting films. Two passengers accidentally meet on a train. Bruno Anthony (Robert Walker) offers to kill the wife of Guy Haines (Farley Granger), if Guy in return murders Bruno’s father. The excellent script was co-written by Raymond Chandler and the film features a climax in a fairground which is among Hitchcock’s finest directing moments.

results.title: Straight time
results.creator_credit: Sweetwall Productions, First Artists, Warner Bros Pictures, Stanley Beck, Tim Zinnemann and Ulu Grosbard
results.brief_description: Dustin Hoffman plays Max Dembo, a small time criminal paroled out of prison who desires to go straight. Initially Dembo’s main obstacle is his parole officer, Earl, who, aware of the power he wields, appears determined to ruin Dembo’s chance for a legitimate life. Living in a depressing half way house, Dembo attains a job in a factory and is soon dating a young woman unaccustomed to a man with Dembo’s past. Frustrated by the conditions of his parole, Dembo is drawn to old ties, and despite the fact that one friend has gone straight, is soon caught up in a web of petty crime. “Straight time” has a gritty urban feel that corresponds to the milieu of the era when American filmmakers were addressing issues of urban isolation, lack of personal freedom and the demise of the American ideals of free will and choice. Hoffman skilfully displays the frustrations of a man whose own incendiary personality coupled with ‘the system’, deny him any real chance at freedom. This was Hoffman’s second collaboration with director Ulu Grosbard, after “Who is Harry Kellerman and why is he saying those terrible things about me?”.

results.title: Storm over Asia = Potomok Chingis-Khana
results.brief_description: Set during the British occupation of Mongolia in 1920, this is the half heroic, half ironic story of Bair, a young Mongolian hunter-turned-partisan who is captured. A document in his possession identifies him as a descendent of Genghis Khan. The interventionists decide to ‘resurrect’ him as a puppet king. However Bair escapes and leads the Mongolian army against the interventionists. The intensity of the drama, strong feeling for landscape and dramatic use of montage (four or five times the usual number of shots for a feature of this length) have been compared with the work of D.W. Griffith. In effect, the film is one long chase which takes on mythic proportions while the plot takes on metaphoric and lyrical dimensions (the British army is literally ‘blown away’). The emotional impact disguises the methodological rigour of Pudovkin’s construction. Also known as The Descendant of Genghis Khan. Cast includes Valeri Inkizhinov. This fully restored and digitally remastered version contains an original score by Timothy Brock performed by the Olympia Chamber Orchestra.
